lines.text: [first lines]

[narrating]
This man came along the trail one Sunday morning in '73, taking it slow and easy, keeping his eyes open and his gun hand ready. He came from nowhere, I guess. Anyhow, he never said from where and we never asked. He was going to stop off in Purgatory, to make his stand like he lived - alone. This is Number One. He called himself Sabin.
When You Ride Into Purgatory, "Say Goodbye to God"
[holding a replica of the "Venus di Milo" statue]
Hey, girls, she's here - the Venus!
Venus who?
Di Milo
Did she ever play Mahogany Hall in New Orleans?
Nah, she's imported from Europe - the most beautiful woman who ever lived.
Sure covers a lot of women.
[after drinking a dipper full of whiskey]
This foul stuff sure tastes good.
I'm no angel.
That's lucky. Angels get the wings singed in Purgatory.
Last night, a couple of ranchers lost their herds.
Is that so? Probably just some of the boys lettin' off a little steam.
They're lettin' off a little lead, too. One of the ranchers got killed.

Sabin, take a look in that mirror there. You see all those people? The world is covered with a swarm of them like a swarm of ants. So what difference does it make if two or three of 'em get stepped on.
Like you?
Now what you ought to do is take a good, long ride for yourself.
I've been told that before. I don't like it.
Oh? In that case, you can mail these letters for me on the way out.
Naco, Brown, Quijano...
The three fastest guns in the territory. You know 'em?
Only by reputation. You sendin' for 'em?
Could be birthday cards. But you could, uh, tear up those letters if you wanted to take that ride.
That would be tamperin' with the government mail.
Johnny Naco, Quijano and a man they call Farmer Brown...
Happy birthday.

[narrating]
Saban first - this is Number Two... Quijano. He had one of those letters from Hoag in Purgatory.
I was just readin' somethin' that all town tamers ought to read. "Gather ye rosebuds while ye may/ For all time is flying. / And at my back I always here / Death's winged chariot hurrying near."
We had a town meeting after church today I proposed you for marshal, Marshal.
You what?
Now don't get sore. They voted not to.
You do a fool trick like that again and I'll run you out of town! Now get out of here! Get!
Fine thing a fella gettin' thrown out of his own jail.
Marshal Becker's dead!
Well, I guess that takes care of getting any legal action against Hoag. We'll have to handle this ourselves.
What do you mean "we"? I ain't no deputy.
[Sabin hands Dipper a deputy badge]
Oil for the door hinges.
Johnny Naco. That's Johnny Naco's game; pretendin' to be lazy and careless and slow.

Farmer Brown they called him. He used to gamble down on Larimer Street in Denver. Never carried a gun; never needed one, till one day a young punk shot him in the face. He became a killer - a fast one.
Looks like you got a customer for your blacksmith shop.
Ahh. Ornery lookin' critter, ain't he.
Looks like he's thrown a shoe.
I mean the rider.
You're certainly fixing things up around here, Mr. Sabin.

Well, uh-uh, Dipper wanted to build a new gunrack and a few odds and ends. He's goin' to put some shelves over here and, yeah, we've got a new chandelier - imported all the way from Perkins' General Store. Now you might tell your husband. He likes to import things.

You stood up to Quijano. Maybe you can face the others who will come to kill you, but you'll be destroyed by a man who's without a gun - a man you can't shoot because he can't stand up to you in the only kind of fight you understand... a gunfight. When he broke his back, he beat every fast gun in this country. He's a cripple, Sabin, and such a man can hold a pass against you.
I'll tell you something about a man who lives by the gun - he'll never have a happy woman.
You don't sound a woman pleading for her man.
I'm not!
I have no woman to plead for me.
Then you're going through with it?
Till death us do part.
How did you get started in this business of yours?
With a marriage certificate.
Sorry.
How did you get started in your present business?
With a gun.
Sorry.
Did you hear something?
Ahh, I'm not sure.
Why did you come for a walk with me if you were so suspicious?
Did you ever hear of a lady named Salome?
The girl who wanted John the Baptist?
The same. When she couldn't have him, she demanded his head on a silver platter.
Did she get it? Well, did she?
...Mm-hmm.
You're damned right she did!
Just a minute - I got somethin' for you.
[Dipper hands Tom a piece of paper]
Why don't you learn to spell "resignation"?
Well, I can spell quit!
Somebody die?
Called himself Farmer Brown... a gambler. Seems he got caught bluffin'.
Tom... Tom, I love you, but I'll stand by Hoag like I always have. I'm his wife.
If you say you're his wife and you're true to him, then you're his wife.
And if you keep things right, then you're the marshal.
I'm no marshal.
I'm no wife.

[toasting]
To you, Johnny Naco! You made him run like a yellow dog, huh?
You paid me enough to kill him, but not enough to make me do what I'm doin' to him.
Well, what is it you want, Johnny?
Your life.
Won't it ever stop? Must it be your own brother now?
Once I stop I'm dead. Can you stop?
I thought I could, but when it came right down to it, I really couldn't. I guess it runs in the family.
Well, so long, Tom.
You can mean that two ways, Johnny boy.
[Tom and Johnny draw their guns and fire]
[last lines]

[narrating]
This was in '73, the land of the man with a gun - some fast, others a little faster... one the fastest of them all.
